Definitely an adventure item.So the sushi was awesome overall and definitely filling because the rolls were huge in size and pieces. So the best part was when our super sweet server saw me take a pic of the gorgeousness she said "hey, if you upload your picture at sushi X on instagram, I'll get you a free dessert." Now that gets a star in itself. I love that kind of service, since I would have probably done it anyway. We ended up trying the mango mousse cake with some mochi ice cream, which was light and a great way to end the meal. So Sushi X is definitely worth trying if you're in the area for some good sushi and great service. But I wouldn't come in the winter since the door keeps opening and it gets a little chilly inside since the place isn't huge.

41.description: Ordered Sushi X the other day via Seamless, and had a terrible experience. Shortly after placing the online order, a Seamless employee called me to say that Sushi X called them to say that one of the items we ordered (veggie gyoza) was "too heavy" and they couldn't make it. (??) A few minutes later, a Sushi X employee called me and spent five minutes complaining about how terrible Seamless is, how their customer service is awful, it's a horrible organization, etc., and that next time I should order through GrubHub or the restaurant directly. Okay...fine. She clarifies the gyoza thing (which still didn't make sense), and says the delivery guy is walking out the door with my order. Forty-five minutes later, nothing. I call Sushi X back and talk to a very hyper and defensive guy who says the delivery guy "left his cell phone at the restaurant" so he can't call him to check on our food. He says I need to wait a full 60 minutes before he can "make it up to me." Not encouraging. Needless to say, the delivery guy never showed up so I called back and the same hyper guy answered and was even more defensive and rude. I said we wanted to cancel the order, and he seemed pleasantly surprised... like he was glad that is all I wanted to rectify the situation. Sounded like this wasn't the first time customers were unhappy with their delivery service. Anyways, I asked him to confirm it would be cancelled and we wouldn't be charged. Yes, yes of course, he assured me and hung up. My husband checked his online cc statement and what do you know... Sushi X charged us for the full order. Can't wait to call back and deal with that. Never again.

52.description: Great spot, cool atmosphere and a trendy vibe to it.  We try to come to Sushi X at least 2 or 3 times per month.  It's BYOB which is fabulous, the staff is super friendly.  The sushi is great, can choose between extra large rolls or the regular size rolls.  Appetizers are great and the portions are huge - highly recommend the asparagus beef roll, the hibachi scallops and the spicy tuna tacos.  All the rolls and sushi/sashima are awesome, and each month they have a special roll that is 1/2 off.

50.description: Get the sushi fruit, and you will not be disappointed.  This is my new favorite sushi spot in Chicago.  You may pass this place everyday and never know the restaurant exits.  But, it does, I promise you.  The exterior is very unwelcoming, but that is not indicative of the service.  The waitress was very friendly and the sushi was remarkable.Also, find the hidden ninja, and get some free mochi.  Who doesn't love ninjas and free dessert?

4.description: Haven't been here in months. the place is getting a big cramped, especially last friday. that said, the rolls are awesome - great taste, texture, presentation. music still is too loud for my aging ears but i love the energy of this place.

6.description: Sushi is my absolute favorite. If I had to choose a last meal on earth, it would be Sushi. Anytime I can't think of what to eat, I default to Sushi. In other words, I love Sushi.Sushi X, on the other hand, I don't love as much. I ordered delivery from Sushi X and while quick and prompt with their service, I couldn't eat half of my order due to the quality of the fish.I got a SPICY SALAD with spicy tuna that came with avocado and spicy mayo dressing. I asked for little (or no) mayo and the restaurant definitely honored that request by omitting the mayo from the dressing. That said, perhaps it's because I altered the dressing but the fish, itself, tasted RANCID. It smelled fishy, it tasted fishy... it made me gag. I could not stomach the salad and ended up throwing it away, much to my great dismay.I also got a SILVER HAZE BOWL with sashimi, lettuce, cucumber, scallions, masago, shiso leaf, carrots, daikon and soybean sprouts, sesame oil, nori flakes, and silver haze sauce (spicy red pepper vinegar sauce). This is basically your Korean "hwe dup bap" but better. I loved the julienned daikon and carrots but felt like the raw soybean sprouts were too potent and detracted from the other flavors. The silver haze sauce is essentially Korean "cho-gochujang" and was very welcome because IT IS SURPRISINGLY IMPOSSIBLE TO FIND IT IN CHICAGO /end rant. Again, some of the fish tasted rancid so I had to pick them out but, overall, after picking out the soybean sprouts and rancid fish, this was an excellent entree and I would order again.Maybe it was an off day, maybe the fish was off. I would reorder because I loved the Silver Haze Bowl and am hoping the rancid fish was a fluke.

22.description: From the outside, it looks like a night club. When you walk in, it looks like a former nightclub....but very small. It has a large screen playing old Anime movies which is pretty cool .Our waitress was really sweet. The food is good but it pretty much has your standard sushi restaurant menu with the gyoza, seaweed salad etc. apps and then the usual sushi rolls. They do have a nice selection of more complex sushi rolls and I got the megatron roll - good but just had too much stuff in it so the flavors of all the different items' seemed to cancel each other out.I would recommend Sushi X because it's inexpensive and it BYOB!

15.description: Love this place!  Been here a few times.  Byob, friendly staff and cool music and vibe.  The coconut shrimp was really good and all their rolls are great! The giant larger ones will really fill you up so if you're hungry would recommend that. Every month they also have a roll on special but you have to ask! Got the crab Rangoon roll, the mango, the jalapeño roll and some other ones.. All super freaken amazing!  It's super small tho so you might be waiting if you come during a busy time and I don't think they take reservations.  Def recommend this place for a cute date night!

57.description: My go-to sushi place. The dinning room is cute but small. I live near by and get take out from here a lot. Best sushi in the neighborhood if you ask me. The rolls are fresh and you can taste all the various favors. Everything there is good but a few of my favorites are: the white tiger, the Buddha roll, double stack, omega roll,  Godzilla roll and sweet potato roll is warm & sweet. The spicy tuna tacos are the spicy tuna roll mix in a taco: really good sushi alternative.  Buddha roll is great for vegans and they even have a roll with spicy chicken if you want. There is a lot of sushi around here and sushi-X is a winner.

20.description: Food was really good, huge rolls and huge menu!  Miso Soup and Oyster shots really good!  Yellow jacket, Black widow and Maui Waui were all really good!  The decor was cool, Just think the place is really dark.

36.description: I have been to Sushi X twice now and held out writing a review. The first time a friend and I arrived we bailed after waiting 20 minutes with no end in sight. The place doesn't have a waiting area which is inconvenient to say the least. If I have to wait for a table at least give me somewhere to stand and maybe enjoy a glass of wine or beer while I am waiting. On a side note, the place is BYOB, which everyone loves. Attempt #2: Same friend and I met again and decided to pop in early in hopes of getting a table. Mission accomplished! The whole place is somewhat small and can get loud but I feel that is to be expected in most trendy places nowadays.We started out with the usual edamame and gyoza. They were pretty typical with what is served at other sushi places. We ordered from the Mega side of the menu. The dragon fly was great, the sushi fruit was different (not to my liking) and another staple, the spider. There is a reason these are on the "mega" side of the menu. The portions are exactly what they say - mega. Attempt #1: My friend and I met at Sushi X again dinner. Again we were seated right away. We got there around 6:30 pm on a Saturday this time. This time we thought we would venture out of our normal appetizers, so we tried the sashimi carpaccio. There were nice cuts and variety of sashimi and I enjoyed the lightly balsamic touch. We ventured out on the menu you a little more this time. We ordered from the Zero section - bombshell, which I was pleasantly surprised. We also ordered the Red Dragon from the Inside Out section of the menu, The various ideas Sushi X has are cool. Both times I was happy with the quality of the fish, however, when a sushi requires two or three bites I get a little annoyed. I want to be able to enjoy the roll in its entirety. The atmosphere is very upbeat, however, the place is somewhat cramped and can get very noisy. Each time we were here street parking was relatively easy; however, I have a feeling that is not always the case.

14.description: Solid!!! Cool atmosphere (Japanese anime meets Crate and Barrel)...prices are remarkably low...byob which is not uncommon. Combine excellent service, no crowds, excellent quality sushi, extensive menu selection, and great prices = new go to place!!! It's going into our regular rotation. You won't be disappointed!!!!

28.description: Looking for a dart joint by the Merchandise Mart, the internet magically whipped up City Pool Hall. Unsure of whether these darts would be steel or soft tipped, I decided the trek out to City Pool Hall. Navigating from River North to City Pool Hall is like playing Legend of Zelda and going through those mountainous areas with spiders jumping back and forth. I had to go through areas with no sidewalks and zip past some factories and walked mainly on gravel. I got to City Pool Hall and noticed the amount of space in the bar. It doesn't hurt to have pool table after pool table after pool table and a beer of the month. I asked where the darts where and I was taken to a back room for darts and was delighted to see they had eletronic and corkboard darts. I also found a bucket full of mangled soft-tipped darts but really paid no mind to it as I whipped out my own set of steel darts.Off I went throwing watching shot after shot deflect off the board as if it was protected by magic aura. Magic aura my ass! I went up to examine both boards and started to notice that the spider (metal wire frame of the dartboard) was raised off the board! To hit a bullseye, you would have to shoot through the raised metal ring around it and have the dart stick in! Also the scoreboard was a mirrored surface with black stuff that you could use chalk to write on but the black stuff was gone and only the mirror remained!For pool players this may be a better bar as they have plenty of tables and people ready to play but I think the table fees may be a bit steep. The food menu is pretty cheap and is typical bar fare. For darts this is a place to hit up if desperate, boards are poorly maintained and need work!

1.description: Ummmm... how did I not know about this place before? Good food, drinks, amazing service and on and on. They are even dog friendly! I'll be back, and I'm bringing Hank. Awww... Hank.

9.description: I have been to this pool hall twice and both times I entered the doors before 1:30 am,  they turned down my buisness because they said I  was too late and it was passed the time that they allow people to play.  On yelp it clearly says it closes at 2am and on the door.  They refused money for 40 whole mins for nothing, a game of pool takes 30 mins if you know what your doing and they should really change the rule or maybe the bartender was being lazy and just wanted to be rude because she had a long day.  Whatever the case is every peny counts in a buisness like a poolhall and the employees customer service is very important.

29.description: This is one of the best pool halls in the city. Relatively new on the scene but it's fair better 99% of the other attempts. The service is awesome, selection of spirits is solid plus what you'd expect in domestic & foreign bottles. The food is decent it's not gonna send you running there for anything but look where it's located in the city you have options! Solid jukebox, go play a couple of racks & get schooled...

23.description: We came here after the awful haunted house near Grand Avenue to drink our bad feelings away.  The beers are cheap, the food was good, and the pool tables were decent.  For a pool hall in the city that serves drinks and food it's very good.

5.description: Great place for pool. Went with a lady friend and there was more than enough pool tables to prevent any prolonged waiting in fact we got ours immediately.  Full bar and enough space. Kept clean and nice.  Casual setting so don't have to worry about feeling out of place should you want to avoid  dressing like you're going to prom . Would go back again and intend to.

31.description: One of my favorite places to hang out in the city - good tables, reasonably priced food and drinks, darts and Golden Tee.  Not a big fan of the jukebox system (periods of silence and others' bad taste really messes with my pool mojo), but since I almost never have to wait for a table, it gets my vote.

25.description: Hung out here on a Friday night. They were open late, they serve great drinks, they serve decent food, they serve it with a smile and they check on you often. We had parking out front and a table as soon as we walked in...This place ROCKS!!!!!

12.description: I wrote the below review 6 years ago, and I've been going to City Pool Hall with semi regularity for... the past 6 years. I've become much more familiar with CPH.The manager. Short, stout, bitchy. My friends and I are on leagues and frequent CPH. Sometimes 2-3 times a week for some of them, (I'm once/week) all of us eating, drinking, during otherwise slow times. And yet, CPH wants to raise our league rates again. Some thanks, huh?The tables are very nice and very well taken care of, the food is generally good, (my favorite are the pretzels, though I will also vouch for the tuna melt and their piece de resistance, their fajitas- YUM. Comes out sizzling- delish!) the waitstaff is usually very attentive, and all else considered, this isn't a bad spot. What they need to learn is that a little customer appreciation goes a long way.

37.description: CPH is great, I play out of there weekly. They have a total of 9 Brunswick Goldcrowns, 6 of them are 9 footers and 3 are 8 footers. The tables are in great shape. They were refelted around new years. All are level and true (except 1 that seems to roll to the inside a little on one side when you shoot soft (#3)).The food is pretty damn good for a pool hall. Most customers agree, the steak fajitas are the best thing on their menu. I've never had anything there that I wouldn't order again and I've tried over 50% of the menu.They have APA leagues out of there on Tuesday, Wednesday, and Thursday so it's difficult to get a table those nights. Monday nights they have another league but it only uses half the tables.The jukebox usually has decent music mixed in with the crap. It's one of those that can retrieve songs via the net if it doesn't already have it loaded. They usually keep it at a level that you can still talk to people across the long end of the table without shouting which is nice.Parking isn't very difficult, you can usually find a spot right in front. They're metered but I don't think they come by and check them often. That said, parking is $2.00 an hour with the new meter price hikes.There are a couple of dart boards and video games in the back and an outdoor patio. The Bar is pretty well stocked. Tables are half priced before 4pm on Saturday. And they are closed on Sundays.

21.description: Granted I didn't shoot pool or eat anything. I came to watch my brother and cousin play in the afternoon. No one else was shooting pool, but there was a bunch of guys at the bar, but they all slowly left. We ended up being the only ones there. Place is clean and decent size. Felt very comfortable there. Good location since it's a bit hidden from the busy path and there are metered parking ($3.00/hour).  Seems they have tons of drink specials everyday of the week.

16.description: Crack! The whack of the balls hitting each other on the tables, the sound of balls in play, and balls being racked, all resonate through the place. What? Me in a pool hall? Surely the world has revolved off it's axis! But City Pool Hall isn't your "normal" pool hall. Now growing up- we always had an 8 foot table in our basement. I loved that single slate table covered in green felt. My dad kept that thing in perfect shape and spent hours teaching us the fine skill, patience and "eye" for pool. But it has been years since I've picked up a cue- but just the smell of chalk sent me back to another place and time. City Pool Hall is a bit hard to find, "hidden" at the end of Hubbard and Des Plaines. There are 3 eight foot tables and 6 nine foot tables. There is also a room in the back for bar darts (still my fav) The place serves breakfast, lunch and dinner until 11pm and has a large bar circling the front room. If you get there after 11pm- no problem- they'll even whip you up a couple of 9" pizzas to stave off the hunger while you play. This is not the pool hall that my mom warned me about. Rather, a well lit, easy to park by, excellently serviced, pool hall full of people (mostly men on the night I was there) who are willing to enter into a game or two with you and share some beers and conversation. Music is varied but played at a level that you can still carry on a conversation. And no matter what your skill level- you can be sure to have a good time. Thwack, goes the break! Oops- that's my cue. Time to go and see if I can actually remember some of the tips my dad gave me so I don't embarrass my friend who brought me here! Now are we solids or stripes? Hmmmm . . . . . . .

17.description: CPH is great, I play out of there weekly. They have a total of 9 Brunswick Goldcrowns, 6 of them are 9 footers and 3 are 8 footers. The tables are in great shape. They were refelted around new years. All are level and true (except 1 that seems to roll to the inside a little on one side when you shoot soft (#3)).The food is pretty damn good for a pool hall. Most customers agree, the steak fajitas are the best thing on their menu. I've never had anything there that I wouldn't order again and I've tried over 50% of the menu.They have APA leagues out of there on Tuesday, Wednesday, and Thursday so it's difficult to get a table those nights. Monday nights they have another league but it only uses half the tables.The jukebox usually has decent music mixed in with the crap. It's one of those that can retrieve songs via the net if it doesn't already have it loaded. They usually keep it at a level that you can still talk to people across the long end of the table without shouting which is nice.Parking isn't very difficult, you can usually find a spot right in front. They're metered but I don't think they come by and check them often. That said, parking is $2.00 an hour with the new meter price hikes.There are a couple of dart boards and video games in the back and an outdoor patio. The Bar is pretty well stocked. Tables are half priced before 4pm on Saturday. And they are closed on Sundays.

10.description: Granted I didn't shoot pool or eat anything. I came to watch my brother and cousin play in the afternoon. No one else was shooting pool, but there was a bunch of guys at the bar, but they all slowly left. We ended up being the only ones there. Place is clean and decent size. Felt very comfortable there. Good location since it's a bit hidden from the busy path and there are metered parking ($3.00/hour).  Seems they have tons of drink specials everyday of the week.

11.description: This and South Port lanes are my pool halls of choice.  Guess I would call it pool North or South.  This place is pretty plan but the tables are in great shape.  Decent cocktails and solid beer selection.  Usually a special on a Saturday or Friday night that's a good deal.  $3 bottles of something actually decent.  Wait staff is friendly and attentive so my drink never goes empty.  No frills but good pool so when on the west or south side I would hit this place for pool.

26.description: This a great place to hang out and catch up with your friends and practice your game. The music is good and not too loud. The pool and drink prices are very reasonable. The lights are bright and keep you more alert than being in a dimly lit clubby pool hall. Our waitress was really nice.

27.description: This place is close to the job and fills a need. Looks like a great place to play pool as they have many tables. I occasionally go here because it's cheap, and also unpretentious. They do have a small out door area, and if your a smoker you can bring your drink and smoke it up. The place does serve food, but I have never tried. I want to like this place more... but it just gives me a bad vibe a lot of the time. I go here when I have a small group of people and that usually helps my uncomfortableness from my surroundings.

35.description: This is a great spot in an area I had absolutely no idea would have a pool hall!  We didn't eat or drink anything here so I won't speak to anything but the billiards itself.  City Pool Hall has nine solid looking tables, with some 9-footers and some 8-footers.  The felt runs true and is unmarred.  The cues are straight.  If you can make it in the middle of the day, you pay only $5 per person per hour.  Good deal!Parking is super easy and when we were in the crowd was extremely sparse.  Plenty of room to maneuver.  I am definitely looking forward to my next visit here.

8.description: Real nice environment played a very versatile playlist of music. Several tables to choose from, good parking. I went on a Saturday night and didn't pay for parking. There are payboxes outside though so I'm sure on weekdays you have to pay. There is a real nice friendly older woman that works the register who says she's worked there for 15 yrs so that shows they know how to treat their employees. Will def return to this place. The alcohol may be a but pricy, we paid $5 for a corona but on the flip side to this you can go in and out so if you have something in the car you can always make the trip back and forth. So I'm giving them a 4 simply because the price of the beer lol

0.description: If you're looking for a spot to play pool and grab a low key drink this is just it.  Tucked away in River West where there is no pretentious crowd you can enjoy getting to know your date and practicing some hand and eye coordination.I live so close and never thought that this would be a spot I would ever go to.  The servers are nice and the music and TVs are always on.  I would say if you are looking for a no fuss or muss place to just hang out check out this fine old establishment.

38.description: I went with my wife recently on a weekend night. We ate there before playing a few games of 8-ball.First, let me say, food is not their strong card. It was edible and that's about it. The service was spot on though. No complaints there.We went there, however, to play pool. The place started to fill up by the time we left but, for the most part, found that we had plenty of space. TV's everywhere to watch the game in between shots. There seemed to be as many women as men in the place shooting, which is always nice. The tables were not inexpensive but we felt there was good value, especially since we able to drink while we shot. What's up with that, by the way? Pool halls should be able to serve beer. Chicago 'halls don't always do that for whatever reason...

20.description: One of my favorite hangouts in the city! Excellent ambiance, great food and the friendliest staff ever! Make sure to visit on weekends when there's always open tables and the greatest waitress ever.  Parking is easily available and groups are easily accomodated.

19.description: This is a great neighborhood bar. Great people, great staff, and good food.

33.description: I play pool, so that I'm a fan is a given. . .however, THEY GOT A NEW CHEF!!! I swear the hot dog I ordered had been marinated in some kind of amazing seasoning. It was a Chicago dog with that unnatural green relish. . .but man! It was so good. . .But. This review isn't for the pool (excellent!) or the Chicago Dog (fabulous!), it's for the apple dumpling! Flakey pastry, hot, cinnamony like crazy. . .just no vanilla ice cream...OMG. If you like apple dumplings, I'm not sure there's a better one in CHICAGO. Go for the pool - stay for the dumpling. . .I am not kidding. It was that good.

2.description: This feels like a secret hiding place. It's tucked away at the end of the street on Hubbard, and I would never have known about it if my boyfriend hadn't driven by and brought me here. We were seated outside per our request and it was such a nice day with no humidity. We came on a day where there were $5 margaritas, so guess what this girl had?! It was the perfect summer drink! The wings were totally hit the spot, and my Fast Eddie sandwich I had was fantastic. I was really impressed that this spot out of the way could have such great food. Our waitress was pretty cool, too. We will definitely be back here. I can see us becoming regulars and that's not something that I do on the regular.

34.description: After our Hot Doug's session, Ben K and I wanted something to do for a couple hours this afternoon.  When we decided playing pool was going to be the answer, we had a smallish dilemma.  Where to go play pool in the middle of the Monday afternoon if you don't want to drink booze?  (We both felt a little weird about going into a bar, ordering a water or coke, and just playing there.)  A preliminary search of poolhalls rendered a few answers, but some were out of date.  For example, Corner Pocket on Halsted still has listings that allude to it being open.  (Not the case.)Enter City Pool Hall.  Located at the intersection of Hubbard and DesPlaines, and flanked by elevated Metra tracks, City Pool Hall is definitely an out-of-the-way destination.  They have a huge floor with 9-foot tables as well as 8-foot tables, a long bar, table seating, and a cool looking outdoor patio in the back.  They have a full bar, and what seemed like decent bar food.  (Club sandwiches, fries, burgers, and the like.)  We chose a 9-footer, and DAYYYMMMNN, those tables are big!  They make the long shots seem even longer with all that green felt in the way.  Table had lots of smooth roll, and Ben pointed out that there was a *slight* lean to one side, although I didn't notice it as we played.  This place was fun, and definitely a place I'm interested in coming back to.  The pool was pretty cheap - $5/person/hour.  I love it's location, and the pool tables are great.  Also, it looks like a great place to watch sports, as TVs abound, each one to a different iteration of ESPN or Sportscenter.  One final, if not rando note: the men's room smells like Spearmint Kodiak Chaw.  Not necessarily a good or bad thing.  Just an observation.  Big fan of this place.

32.description: POOL HALL STEREOTYPES...CORNER POCKETI have to admit I was not thrilled at the prospect of going to a pool hall after the Hawks game.  The words 'pool hall' tend to conjure images of dark, cavernous spaces, suffocating clouds of cigarette smoke, and a-hole patrons just itching to stab you in the neck with a broken beer bottle.  I guess I've been going to the wrong pool halls, because City Pool Hall is nothing like that.CPH is big, bright, and welcoming even to novice pool players like myself.  The servers are attentive (and kinda hot), the drinks are strong, and the bar food is surprisingly good.  It was nice to be in a place where the music isn't so loud that you can actually have a conversation with your friends and just relax.

18.description: We came here after the awful haunted house near Grand Avenue to drink our bad feelings away.  The beers are cheap, the food was good, and the pool tables were decent.  For a pool hall in the city that serves drinks and food it's very good.

13.description: I used to shoot out of here on Tuesday nights. This place is in immaculate condition considering all of the traffic with leagues and regular customers. When you walk in you are greeted by their giant bar...fully stocked of course. About 5 or 6 sit down tables. 12 pool tables that all play very well.The staff is warm and friendly. I really like how their staff is so personable and helpful. The food is really good. This shouldn't be mixed in with your typical bar fare. They change the menu to keep things turning around in the kitchen. They offer healthy alternatives like a house salad with all the trimmings instead of fries. Some of the things their kitchen offers is: Fajitas on a sizzling plate, Meatloaf dinner, pot roast, soup dojour, fried chicken, chicken and steak sammies, etc.City Pool hall offers drink specials almost everyday that include beers and well drinks. The prices are pretty reasonable for the area. I love going here to get lost in the tables with friends. I plan to continue to be a patron of City Pool hall for years to come.

4.description: Did you know at city pool hall they have a loyalty program. You fill out a card they give you a punch card . And if you spend $20.00  or more per visit they will punch that card . After 8 punches they will give  you at $25.00 gift card for you to spend there. Come visit and get your card. We have food and drink specials everyday. We have pool leagues and our pool players get half price off for pool . Come join a team or bring a team . Please stop by and visit.

24.description: I used to shoot out of here on Tuesday nights. This place is in immaculate condition considering all of the traffic with leagues and regular customers. When you walk in you are greeted by their giant bar...fully stocked of course. About 5 or 6 sit down tables. 12 pool tables that all play very well.The staff is warm and friendly. I really like how their staff is so personable and helpful. The food is really good. This shouldn't be mixed in with your typical bar fare. They change the menu to keep things turning around in the kitchen. They offer healthy alternatives like a house salad with all the trimmings instead of fries. Some of the things their kitchen offers is: Fajitas on a sizzling plate, Meatloaf dinner, pot roast, soup dojour, fried chicken, chicken and steak sammies, etc.City Pool hall offers drink specials almost everyday that include beers and well drinks. The prices are pretty reasonable for the area. I love going here to get lost in the tables with friends. I plan to continue to be a patron of City Pool hall for years to come.

6.description: This place is great! I've been going to pool halls since I turned 18 to play some games with friends. This is by far the best maintained pool hall that I have ever been to!The tables are clean, felt is intact, no dings or dents on the slate. Balls are legit! No cheap plastic crappy balls that bounce all over the place here! Pool cues are numerous and of various weights. One of the awesome things about this place include thanking some of the cheapest drinks in the city. It has a "pro shop" where you can buy legit billiard cues and acc. I also love that they have both 8 and 9 foot tables hereIf you want, they have leagues... I wish I had the free tjme for it. But maybe in the future?Staff is courteous and friendly, always coming around asking about refills and if we are ok. Been here multiple times already and never had to wait for a table! They have a modern jukebox and the music is always good plus plenty of screens to watch college or pro football

22.description: Food: Decent bar food. Nothing special. The fries were solid, they used shoe strings (think McDonalds type). Wings were 25c on Mondays.I got an Italian Sausage but the french roll seemed somewhat stale.Someone else had the Swiss Mushroom Burger, and that person said it was good.Workers: No complaints. Friendly.Atmosphere: Default atmosphere for a pool hall.

15.description: Nice place to play pool especially if you play on league nights.  Some nights are quieter than others. Usually go here on weekends if they aren't hosting a tournament. Food is pretty good for a pool hall and the price is fair.  Staff is super friendly.

7.description: I have been on a Wednesday night pool team for about a year now, and this place really is the best. I cannot think of another pool hall where I can bring my ten month old son and shoot around on a Sunday. Or one that has such delicious grass fed steak fajitas. Renee is tough but fair and Phil, the owner is very nice and approachable. There are great places nearby, bari, coalfire, twisted spoke and the pizza place a block away has gluten free pizza. But here the food and service is way beyond average, highest echelon I'd say. I also love how it smells like chocolate often. And I like the community of pools players I've come to know, and beat. I love how there's an outside smoking area, and a professional table with tighter pockets than a hipster at the beach. Juke box can play any song for a dollar and they have a rewards program now. Come here to shoot pool, best in Chicago.

36.description: I only give this place a 3 rating but it leans toward a 4, cause it is usually an empty place where it is not difficult to find and table and set up for some pool playing. The place is clean and seems modernized. The specials are usually decent and music is juke box so it is what it is. The crowd is usually a diverse group with people using City Pool Hall as a meeting point to and from other places. The food is edible but unlike Roosevelts in MI, this place does not compare. The size is also stuck between a real pool hall and a bar. It was as if the management got confused and decided to stick 9 pool tables in a bar. The location is perfectly secluded so that it is not ever over run with people and it is usually quiet. Nice place for a slower night out. Play some pool and have a few drinks. As an aside the pool is actually more expensive than I remember. I thought it came out to about $20 per hour. Would rather have spent that on something else cause I suck at pool.

30.description: Crack! The whack of the balls hitting each other on the tables, the sound of balls in play, and balls being racked, all resonate through the place. What? Me in a pool hall? Surely the world has revolved off it's axis! But City Pool Hall isn't your "normal" pool hall. Now growing up- we always had an 8 foot table in our basement. I loved that single slate table covered in green felt. My dad kept that thing in perfect shape and spent hours teaching us the fine skill, patience and "eye" for pool. But it has been years since I've picked up a cue- but just the smell of chalk sent me back to another place and time. City Pool Hall is a bit hard to find, "hidden" at the end of Hubbard and Des Plaines. There are 3 eight foot tables and 6 nine foot tables. There is also a room in the back for bar darts (still my fav) The place serves breakfast, lunch and dinner until 11pm and has a large bar circling the front room. If you get there after 11pm- no problem- they'll even whip you up a couple of 9" pizzas to stave off the hunger while you play. This is not the pool hall that my mom warned me about. Rather, a well lit, easy to park by, excellently serviced, pool hall full of people (mostly men on the night I was there) who are willing to enter into a game or two with you and share some beers and conversation. Music is varied but played at a level that you can still carry on a conversation. And no matter what your skill level- you can be sure to have a good time. Thwack, goes the break! Oops- that's my cue. Time to go and see if I can actually remember some of the tips my dad gave me so I don't embarrass my friend who brought me here! Now are we solids or stripes? Hmmmm . . . . . . .

3.description: Thought this place would be awesome, and it is if you're in one of their pool leagues. Otherwise, expect terrible service, overpriced drinks, and universal unavailability. Again, if you come here, seems like a great place. But if you're new, DO NOT COME HERE.

14.description: Not normally the type of place I'd go to but when I scheduled a lunch meeting nearby at the Point without realizing the Point isn't open for lunch we stopped in here.The veggie wrap with chicken was delicious and the staff very friendly.Not a gourmet or fancy place but they have some good options even for a bar setting.

28.description: Most unhelpful pharmacy, one time I needed to have my script transferred to another store because I wasn't going to make it there by 10 p.m to pick it up, the answer was no. Hmm Walgreens does it. Another time I was shorted 20 bucks in change at the drive through.Tonight, I guess the pharmacy closes at 6 or 8, I'm not sure but it seems early for a Saturday night. I will be moving my scripts for sure.Then since I was there I decided why waste the trip, better pickup milk, a line of about twenty people deep. Are you kidding me? So I put the milk back and leave.A note to CVS corp, this is the first of two reviews that will be both one star. Staff your stores with good hires, people hate lines and other weirdness.

1.description: This place is an embarrassment.They force customers to work there a la self checkout. Anytime checkout requires a coupon, or if checkout is going smoothly, the whole thing stops,  blinks and requires an associate to type in some numbers to move it along. There are 5 checkout stations yet 15-20 people generally waiting to checkout and every station is blinking that it requires assistance. No one actually works at the register. In an economy such as this, people need jobs, so wtf happened here? Everything is done by computer; yet even those are incompetent!!!Product placement is beyond misleading.Parking lot is tiny.Pharmacist handled a syringe with her bare hands and when I asked for a sealed one she said that was the only one I could get. Gross.

9.description: huge homeless problem here.you're pretty much guaranteed to be harassed by 1 or more shady looking characters lurking outside the front entrance begging for money (and yelling at you if you don't give any).I've brought it up to the manager, who says there's nothing they can do.I called CVS corporate, they say it's the store's problem.end result, I now go somewhere else.

29.description: Very nice pharmacy staff, but incompetent. Unfortunately, being nice doesn't cover everything when you are dealing with medications that can cause very severe problems if mishandled. I will never go to another CVS again, particularly this one, for prescriptions. Problems: In February I received someone else's medication and had to bring it back. In May I set up the auto-fill option. Twice now I have gotten calls saying they are ready and when I go in, they are not ready. Fine, but what's the point of the auto-fill calls? Also, despite asking multiple times to change my contact information, they are still calling my parents in Ohio (I haven't lived there in 5 years). This week (July 7), I was charged for 3 months of pills and received 1, so had to go back. Also this week, I asked for both of my prescriptions, but they said one needed an authorization, even though my bottle said there was one more. I called my doctor and she called CVS to refill it. I went back and she said it had been ready all along, but she thought there was a change. Why would she think that if neither me nor my doctor said there would be a change? Excuse for incompetency I guess. I am now behind on my medication by 2 days, which is ok for me, but for more serious medication, this could be a real issue.They say you should choose your pharmacist as closely as you would your physician, advice I will now heed. I highly recommend moving your prescriptions away from CVS. Even if they are nice, a medication error can be very, very serious. Please don't support a company that has as many issues as this one (look up CVS complaints online and you'll see they have nation-wide issues), especially on something as important as medication.

23.description: Ha! The negative reviews for this place pretty funny. I mean, the store is filled with some crazy ppl at times, don't get me wrong, but I agree with Kelsey M.  It's a CVS! LOL!I am giving this a 4 based on the pharmacist alone. Went in asking for a recc for OTC cold medicine....she asked me my symptoms, we talked about boogers/snot/mucus, what the color and consistency of mine were like, what that meant, and how I should proceed.I think I felt so gross I was pretty sure I said, "my boogers are green and kind of thick?"  I bet if she rated me, she'd probably give me a 1....For the record, I'm no longer a snot filled person and am on the road to recovery.

5.description: This place is THE WORST place to go to, staff are I competent and rude, machines don't work...I advise to NEVER come to this location.

31.description: The store itself may be your classic convenience store hole, but the pharmacy is wonderful.  The good folks who work behind the florescent-lit counter are friendly, on-the-ball, and will take the brain-space needed to remember you next time.If you would like a regular pharmacy to get your Rx from, go here.  If you need some advice, go ask them.  If you need to grab your prescription and a pack of toilet paper and a candy bar, they'll ring you up and smile doing it.

25.description: Maybe it's because it's like a second home to me by now, but I have few problems with this CVS. I guess the ones I do have should warrant a lower star rating, but I just can't do it to them! The people who work there are insanely nice, at least to me, and anyone else who seems to engage them. I saw the first loud customer situation in 3 years today, where a girl was trying to return a phone and they wouldn't let her... She swore up and down and called the lady several nice names, and we later found out it was the third phone she tried to return...Anywho, The lines can be long, but usually move fast. It annoys me when people don't line up along the cassette tapes and photo area, and instead spread all out into the impulse-buy-table area; I mean, are you new or something?They should start putting Vitamin Water on sale a lot more, but they often have good deals on vodka and cold medicine...

12.description: The friendliest CVS ever and the cashier Anne was very helpful. My cvs card doesn't work sometimes. And she was the only who explained me what to do. Oh and there's wide choice of cosmetics which is great.

21.description: Great location, clean, with easy parking. Also a US bank in the parking lot... this place works for me!

16.description: Ha! The negative reviews for this place pretty funny. I mean, the store is filled with some crazy ppl at times, don't get me wrong, but I agree with Kelsey M.  It's a CVS! LOL!I am giving this a 4 based on the pharmacist alone. Went in asking for a recc for OTC cold medicine....she asked me my symptoms, we talked about boogers/snot/mucus, what the color and consistency of mine were like, what that meant, and how I should proceed.I think I felt so gross I was pretty sure I said, "my boogers are green and kind of thick?"  I bet if she rated me, she'd probably give me a 1....For the record, I'm no longer a snot filled person and am on the road to recovery.

17.description: No complaints,they have pretty much everything that you need,it's clean,and plenty of parking ^^

10.description: I have been coming here since this was an Osco.  An OSCO!  Since I first moved to the city and lived across the street.  Its a CVS now. And has been for quite some time.   I mean, I think we all wish it was still a stand alone Osco, but its a CVS - with carpet, weird signs to locate their items, a horrible self-checkout system and generally long lines.Why do I give it 4 stars?  The Pharmacy is great!  Drive-thru is fast and the pharmacists are SO friendly and helpful!Go easy folks.

11.description: I am an East Coast girl, so I am very CVS indoctrinated. I agree Walgreens looks shinier and newer, but you don't get to be East Coast without being a little rough. I really like this CVS because the staff is uber friendly and helpful. I hate the self-checkout stations, but I haven't been here once without a friendly greeting. Still, the food selection leaves much to be desired, and since I feel like this area is a food desert, it would be nice to have a better selection of groceries i.e. produce (not prepackaged 8-day old oranges), healthy prepared foods (not ugly old sandwiches) and decent cheese and pasta sauce (not Kraft singles and Ragu).

26.description: My experiences with CVS have not been the best as I try to patronize home grown Walgreen's as my first choice.However, what I really, really hate about CVS is the carpeting.  When shopping in a drug/convenient store I want to get in and out.Their wall to wall carpeting does nothing but hopefully slow down their customers in hopes they will make more unnecessary purchases.  Screw the carpeting, I'm not shopping in a Dept. Store.

27.description: Sweet baby Jeebus, this place is busy...at all hours of the day and night.  Might it have something to do with those super nice, super-approachable pharmacists?  I think it might.Last week, I probably would have written a scathing review.  Then, I dropped off a prescription to be filled.  I was swiftly informed it would take the pharmacy 20-30 minutes to fill it.  Ok, that's fine.  After all, there was a crowd of about 20 people hanging out in front of the pick-up counter and cars were busily streaming through the drive-through.  You're busy.  I get it.That, however, does not explain why it took me 1.5 hours to get my antibiotics.  I'm perplexed.  All one had to do was put 5 - count them, one, two, three, four, five - antibiotic pills in a little orange bottle, affix a label and hand over my gosh darned drugs into my greedy, grasping, and shaking hands.  Yup, 1.5 hours.Today, I run in to pick up more antibiotics, some bionic woman strength cough syrup, and steroids.  I'm in and out in under 5 minutes, with a smile on my face.  Oh, and the cutest, tiniest pharmacist man explained to me how to take my steroids and gave me a short but sweet lecture about absolutely, positively not chugging my cough syrup out of the bottle.  Instead, he gave me a beaker slash spoon to measure that shit out.  I need to come up with a name for that dealio.  It's sort of....kind of....like a spork....but a beaker that terminates in a spoon resemling a miniaturized sugar scoop.Oh, sorry, I got off track.  Yes, back with the program.  Pharmacists = caring, friendly, and patient.  Lines = sometimes long as the River Kwai.  (Note to self:  Bad analogy.  Replace with something better once brain is functioning at optimal speed). Will be back to fill more prescriptions if death rattle does not abate.

35.description: Why is this my favorite CVS?+ They are open 24-hours.+ They have a huge beauty/bath section.+ They have a large liquor section.+ They have all my necessary cleaning products.  Even Murphy's Oil Soap!  + Super friendly staff.+ Large magazine section if you're waiting to fill a prescription.+ Large parking lot for drivers.

0.description: This CVS is located on the corner of Milwaukee and Chicago.  A very convenient location with the bus and CTA Blue line only steps away.I don't think there was a card minimum here which is a bonus.  They also had "fresh produce", a few bananas.  Again, this isn't that major but it is a nice option to have fresh fruit if you want it.  I got a couple Gatorades here and a banana after one of my runs.  The service was friendly and actually helped me swipe my card as I was clearly incapable.  They also have self checkout at this location.I prefer someone else check me out.

20.description: The pharmacy's manager is the worst!! she always has bad attitude and even when there is no customers waiting in line....she wont acknowledge  that you are there standing for 15 minutes like a moron!! The when I say hello!!! I'm here.....she gets an attitude. You need to lead by example in front of you co-workers  ....if you can't no longer do that and be nice to the consumers like myself and everyone else....go HOME!!

19.description: I really hate to give a one star review but in the case of CVS I have to. I have been there 3 times counting today and it will be my last. I don't mind that a store has self check out for those who want to self check out but I work to hard and then spend my hard earned money at CVS only to have to check my self out and bag my purchases. The line is very long and there is ALWAYS a problem with at least one of the self check out lanes. I usually go to the Jewel on Des Plaines and Kinzie and they could not be nicer. I will stay closer to home from now on.

33.description: My review is mostly for the pharmacists.  I don't know where CVS finds them, but this store has the nicest, most helpful pharmacists I've seen at a major chain drugstore.  I've gone in several times with various ailments, and in an attempt to avoid going to the doctor, inquired with the pharmacists about which OTC drugs would help me. There are 2 in particular ( I wish I knew their names!) who are very friendly and sympathetic, and do seem to know which drugs work for which problems.  Unfortunately the rest of the staff is just so-so. Everyone's friendly but the lines are always sooooo long.  I guess you really wouldn't go out of your way for any CVS, but if you live in the area, this is much better than any of the Walgreen's around.

2.description: Compared to my last CVS on Kinzie and LaSalle this one is as awesome as a four day weekend. It's open 24 hours, there's a drive through, the staff is nice, there's a Coinstar machine, and they actually open the non self out check lane. Even though I actually did see a car drive through their front window (see pic) it's not that bad of a drug store that you'd want to do something like that.

34.description: CVS in River West: you get one star for selling booze, and the other for staying open 24/7.  But boo for the long, horrendous lines that occur more often than not in the evening.  And an even bigger boo for your unruly patrons.  Yes, it sucks waiting in line. But screaming and borderline abusing the staff isn't going to make much of a difference. Earmuffs for the kids-- unofficial warning to all families.  CVS, you've got a nifty "Extra Buck Rewards" program. Basically, you carry most everything I could need in a pinch.  But I've switched locations, because I moved, and I couldn't be happier.  I can now fill my prescriptions and read that "Us" magazine, er, rag (shhhh) in peace.

32.description: One Star for BeerOne Star for other BoozeNegative for the traffic which isn't their fault however getting a couple more cashier's out on the registers during after work core hours is too simple to NOT be their fault.

18.description: Ever since I moved down the street from this CVS I have despised having to use this CVS for my pharmacy. These people are awful!!! I even called them once asking if I could take two medications together and one of the pharmacists said yes, you sure can. 5 or 6 days later after I was waking up seeing blurry and dizzy in the middle of the night, I called my doctor very concerned and she said stop taking those two immediately, they are known for people hallucinating when mixing. On top of this, it always takes 20 minutes minimum (even in the drive thru!) to get an Rx. Moving in a week and couldn't be happier to not use them anymore!!

13.description: I really, really don't like this CVS.  The first time I came here, I had a small child with me.  Since this was going to be a quick trip for baby wipes, I decided to nix the stroller as I could just grab a cart if necessary.  Well, turns out they only had about 3 carts for customers to use while the rest sat full of products throughout the store.  My next problem came when I needed help with reaching something.  An employee completely ignored me even though I said "excuse me" twice.  When it came time to check out, there was a long line waiting to use the self-checkout with no employee around to help those having trouble with the machines.  Having only self-checkouts and no one around to monitor them created a long wait with an anxious toddler who didn't want to be held and didn't want to hold my hand.  It's often convenient, but I still don't like it.

4.description: Wrost customer service I've encountered in a very long time, literally waited 10mins to be greeted and acknowledge. I understand it's a busy day in the drive in for people to pick up an Rx. A simple "Hello, I'll be with you in a moment" goes a long way. The lady behind the counter made me feel like me being sick was an unconvinance. The cashiers in the front of the store however are  always awesome and usually friendly, which makes the whole thing really disconnected.

24.description: Dudes...it's CVS I'm not sure what is to be expected?  Sure there's a ton of strange folk milling around this place, but come on, watching those characters is what makes the wait in line fly by.  I mean where else will you see a dude pick up a sixer of Bartles and Jaymes and a box of Magnums?  And sure they run out of stuff, but it's located at a very busy intersection in a residential area next to an El stop.  It's bound to happen. Over all I'm pretty happy with my CVS.  The people that work there are always friendly and they usually have everything I need in a pinch.

6.description: This may be the friendliest CVS ever.  They have a door greater.  This is also a large CVS.  The parking here is not easy but it was manageable.  Its one of those corners where 5 or 6 streets "cross" so its a busy area.  Interesting to me, they also sell alcohol here, but I was there early in the am, so that was not relevant for me at the moment.  They also carry pretty much everything else you find in CVS stores, and have a large pharmacy.  The checkout was easy as well.  Overall, this is a fine drugstore.

22.description: Ugh. This place is frustrating. It's a typical CVS, so I have no complains about the products. However, the staff is pretty terrible. They have self-check outs and the employees basically ignore every customer. I've waited in a HUGE line at the self check out while three employees standing behind the checkout counter chatted and laughed the entire time. Really? Really?!

15.description: Low score just to even out my score distribution. I was delighted to find they sell Tullamore Dew here, which is a very smooth yet underrated whiskey. Not to mention at the same price as Johnny Red, you'd be almost outta ur mind to get Red over the Dew. I know I know, no product reviews, got it Yelp police. Staff here nice but maybe that's everyone in Chicago.

7.description: The nice thing about this location is that it has a drive-thru.  It makes it easy to drop off your prescription and then to come and pick it up later when it is ready.  The only thing I hate is when you hit the call button and voice over starts talking to you.  It says, "that someone will be with you as soon as possible."  I am fine with that but the people working behind the window never look over and they will pretend like you are not even there.  I guess it just feels non-personal but they eventually will come over and talk to you.  The drive-thru will save you time...you can avoid the homeless person asking for money by the front door, the security guard profiling you and the long walk to the back of the store where you will always find someone waiting in front of you.As I continue to write this review am I wondering why I am giving them 4 stars because my comments seem a little negative.  I am giving them the 5 stars based off of them always filling my prescription in a timely manner, always filling the prescription correctly and being able to drive in and out quickly.If you do go in...this place has a blood pressure machine, so you can check if you are still alive or about to die.  You can also ask the pharmacist a few questions about certain over the counter drugs and if they will have any negative interactions with current medications you are taking.

8.description: The employees at this CVS are incredibly lazy. This location has self-checkout stations, so they never have a cashier station open. They honestly are taking complete advantage of self-checkout machines and force all customers to go to self check-out. Even though I always see employees in the front of the store standing around and talking about nothing, none of them are rarely courteous enough to open up a cash station for me and personally ring up my items. The so-called "door greeter" actually just stands there to direct you to the self-check out station, because none of them are actually going to do their jobs, go behind the station and actually HELP you get out of the store faster. I guess they think because they have self-check out machines, employees no longer have to do their jobs.

30.description: For whatever reason, this one pharmacy in this huge chain of pharmacies has the most wonderful, sweetest ladies that work here. I recently switched here from Walgreens because of a brand of a drug that they carry and I'm not sure that I've ever been treated nicer at any pharmacy ever. For some reason, pharmacists always have this "I'm too busy for you" air about them, but they are so sweet and helpful here that I simply had to yelp about it.Bonus points for a drive-thru pharmacy. Although I see the irony of it if you're picking up diabetes medicine or something. Being that I don't have any serious health issues, it was really nice not having to get out of my car during a snow storm.

3.description: The staff and the selection are great, however the pharmacy is another story.  The pharmacy is constantly out of stock, and the staff is rude and patronizing. I highly recommend this cvs except for there pharmacy.

14.description: The cash register Bany was too busy talking to her coworker about tatoo she forgot to say: hello, thank you and goodbye. Your customer service is horrible!

58.description: This is quite possibly the best coffee in the city, in my opinion. On top of that, it's organic and they roast it right there in front of your face!! Huzzah! They have some great unique drink options. They also make their own chai tea blend and allow you to sweeten it to your liking which is really really delicious and obviously awesome of them. The staff here are not only some of the best baristas around, but probably some of the best people around. I actually feel more like I'm visiting friends when I'm there instead of getting coffee and working.A nice extra touch, is the large TV screen that has updated weather and blue line train times. Genius.PS - who dared give this place less than 5 stars!? Poppycock!

56.description: Big Shoulders will satisfy the seventh-wave coffee snob and the wayward vagrant alike, with its warm interior, $2.00 bottomless coffees, and all manner of pourovers ("slow drip") and special milky drink options. Baked goods are a little pricey, but what else is new.It is not a place to go for complete quiet, because they actually roast the beans right in there, which creates a decent amount of noise (and heat), but I think that adds to the authenticity, especially amid a stenciled wall with the text from the 1916 Carl Sandburg (back when things were actually made in the city and before everyone was working for tech startups and... coffee shops). Definitely recommend!

29.description: The Cardamom spice latte was very sweet and not especially spicy (I find this is often the case with tea and coffee lattes -- maybe I need to try to modify my ordering...or just stick to plain old lattes, which is sort of boring). The coffee was good, but I wish I'd gone with a basic, unflavored, unsweetened latte instead. It's in a great location right at Chicago and Milwaukee. There's a bike rack right outside. The staff was very obliging, making my latte in my travel mug so that I could take it with me on my bike without disaster. It's also a nice space with big windows, and since it's right on a busy corner I imagine there's some fun people-watching to be done.

42.description: What a great cup of coffee. As their website says "no-nonsense brew delivered fast and hot"  and that's right on the money. And speaking of money it's reasonably priced. But the coffee - well balanced and flavorful- bold but not over the top; fresh roasted beans and perfect brewing does the trick. Very good customer service from the two baristas too.The shop is clean and, in my experiences, not overly crowded. Makes me want to get out the door a bit early to stop in and enjoy my cup before transferring to the blue line. I'm not so much a specialty coffee guy but they have a nice variety on the menu - the marshmallow late looks delicious. Other in house made syrups/infusions. I need to bring my wife here... she loves that kind of thing :).Doing coffee right over there, no doubt about it.

23.description: Nice airy, bright coffee shop.  Right around the corner from the Intuit Museum.I'm still thinking about the spiced hibiscus iced tea.

47.description: Simple!  Good coffee and pastries in a well ventilated, clean comfortable setting with knowledgeable and informative staff.  Now, I have a new list of lattes to taste in house made syrups/infusions.

8.description: Again, just a food truck review, so I can't say much about the physical location on the west side.What can I say about my coffee? I like my coffee like I like my Death Stars. Big, dark, and strong enough to destroy a planet. And while this may be me on the cusp of coffee snobbery, I think weak coffee is the equivalent of pissing into a Keurig.I was dragging myself across Wacker on my way to the office. I hadn't had my morning cup yet, so homicidal thoughts were running pretty high. Just when I thought 20 years in Cook County correctional didn't seem so bad, bam their coffee truck was right there. Literally, I wasn't paying attention to where is was walking and I actually bumped into their coffee truck.Some lady was in front of me taking her sweet ass time completely unaware that she was standing at scene of the July 17th Chicago coffee massacre. (The date this review was written) And just when I had all I could stands and I can't stands no more... she left, a nice young man within the truck provided coffee for $2 (not a bad price) and a disaster was averted.  Seriously, I wash with powdered soap, I totally can't go to prison!  Thank you Big Shoulders Coffee! Oh yeah, the actual coffee... Duh. It wasn't the strongest cup of joe I've ever had, meaning I didn't have to chew it. But it was a nice blend of fragrance and acidity. Overall a good choice. They also have some dessert items on their menu. I can never know if Jenny Craig is reading my reviews, so just to be safe I didn't partake, but you should probably try them. When was the last time you and a brownie didn't get along?

31.description: So I went to sleep at midnight and got up at 4:30 to join a friend for a bicycle ride to Chicago's new "606" 2.7 mile jogging and bike path. I know...what was I thinking?!? This actually very enjoyable trip culminated in heading back to our respective homes, hers in River West and mine in Streeterville, but not before a stop at Big Shoulders Coffee so I'd have an extra hard time getting that second half of a proper 8 hour sleep.While I like lattes, macchiatos, cappuccinos, and other Italian named coffee fare that I don't necessarily understand, I'm kind of a purist who just likes ol' drip coffee. Big Shoulders' "fast drip" was mighty nice. It really puts the V in smooth. No burnt taste here, just rich coffee flavor with no bitterness with a smooth taste that makes me wonder why Starbucks is so damn popular. Oh yeah, well McDonalds and Miller Lite are too.They have a good selection of teas and coffee beans and a few pastries too. Apparently no hot breakfast-y type food to the lament of another reviewer. My pal says their marshmallow latte is excellent while perhaps not appreciating the irony of drinking her coffee black to save calories for "something else."Friendly service and a funkdafied atmosphere. Oh, and free wifi!

34.description: Big Shoulders is another pit stop on my Indie Coffee Passport. If I lived along the blue line, I would make this place my go-to for a cup of coffee.BSC roasts the coffee beans in-house, in-your-face. The roasting machine is located near the entrance, and it's like heaven when you're sitting at the cafe and the smell of freshly roasted beans are wafting to your corner of the cafe. Just like BK, BS will brew your coffee "your way": chemex, pour-over, catila. They have specialty lattes and will allow you to smell the syrup if you're hesitant. Had to choose between cardamom spice and toasted marshmallow today, and as big of a chai tea snob as I am, I went with toasted marshmallow. In-house lattes come in glass cups like chai tea does in India. Thick foam that makes you think you're sipping a melted marshmallow. Unimaginable and incomparable sensation unless you try it for yourself. Service was par-excellence. In-house lattes are brought to you at your table. On Twitter? Tweet about your experience and get any drink for $1. No need to hit up BK for "your way" on the dollar menu. Only thing a-miss? Didn't get a toasted marshmallow on my latte. Kinda sorta came here just for that.

16.description: Yum.  Great after-Mass treat (I was at St. John Cantius just up the street).  I strongly suggest the Marshmallow Latte and the Sonny B- they're both DELICIOUS!

13.description: Pretty cool spot, free WiFi which is great and the staff is awesome! I had a rhubarb scone (delicious) and a chai lattee. The lattee tasted pretty watered down, so I'll be giving their other beverages a try next time.

11.description: Experiencing many different independent coffee shops in Chicago, I have to say the "Colombian", a low acidic, medium roast with notes of praline from Big Shoulders was the most delightful cup of coffee I've had in a while. #bigshoulderscoffee

39.description: It's taken me awhile to write this review, partly because I hold it to such high esteem so I feel the need to make the review commensurate. But screw it, it's time I write this review.Big Shoulders is great. My go-to coffeeshop for great espresso, roasted right inside the shop. The drip is barely too acidic for my taste, but nothing beats Big Shoulders' espresso drinks. Nice baristas that are always approachable.There's about 20 spots to sit, which isn't a lot, but there's always an open space. Ample amount of plugs around the nifty, triangular table that conforms to the shape of the place. If you're lucky, you'll leave with aromatic white flakes on you, coming down from the ventilation once the roasting machine gets roastin'. It's basically free caffeine sitting atop your big shoulders.

37.description: I love this coffee shop so much! The marshmallow latte is my fav! Only 4 stars due to the lack of a bathroom.

0.description: I cannot get enough of this place. Whether you're getting a drip coffee or a specialty latte, everything Big Shoulders touches is fantastic. Great service and delicious brews makes this a no-brainer for any West Towners. Even better, we just recently started bringing their beans home with us to brew on the weekdays.

38.description: I look forward to stopping in (almost) every morning on my way to work.  The staff is friendly and welcoming, the pastries are delicious and the coffee is affordable and is one of my favorites in the city. And while that is all great, what I love most is that you never know what kind of surprise is waiting for you when you walk thru the door...is it a DJ? Free cup of coffee? $1 cup of joe when you ride the cta? They even have a bus tracker so you can enjoy your morning in the stylish space while you wait for the bus/train.

51.description: This place has delicious and strong coffee. I love the different variety of drinks you can get. The Almond Latte w/almond milk is excellent. The atmosphere is very chill and inviting, too. The workers are very, very kind. I feel like they value you as a customer whether they've never seen you before, or see you every day. They make great conversation, are very considerate and kind, and take great care of you. Awesome cafe!

27.description: Best coffee roasters in Chicago. Their light and medium roasts really stand out (especially the unwashed mexico beans when they have them)

32.description: I love this place. It's not on my way to work, in fact it's the opposite way for me. But I often find myself going out of my to go grab coffee in the morning. The space is simple, but really nice. Not too modern, but looks new. The staff has always been as nice as can be. The prices are good, the coffee is amazing. I like to sit by the window and wait as long as I can before catching my train which is located steps from the door. They even have screens with the train and bus trackers! It's a great place for commuters to stop in before work. They have bar seating and a communal table. Since they roast their own coffee, I like to grab a bag and take it to work so I can press my own.

54.description: Served in a "one-size fits all" cup, the coffee is simple in its delivery yet complex in flavor - the kind of cup that represents the nature of the city of Big Shoulders. Depending on what's brewing, you might get a cup that's fruity and bright or rich and chocolate-y; either way, it will taste fresh. If you crave milk and sugar, you'll find your yearning for coffee fused with your childhood love of hot chocolate in the form of a marshmallow latte. A giant marshmallow is roasted, skewered and set over the cup for a drink that is perfectly sweet, not cloying. It's lighter than a traditional cup of marshmallow-studded cocoa, but cozy enough for a Chicago winter's day.

48.description: Great coffee shop.Stopped in to grab some beans, since this place is right on the blue line. Walked in and the first thing you see is someone roasting coffee, which is a good indicator. They have a good selection of whole bean coffee from various locations. When you buy a bag of coffee they give you a complimentary cup to go, which is a nice touch. Also, the barista was super friendly and took the time to describe the different options they had available for my to go coffee. They serve drip, press, clever and chemex to order. And most important, the coffee was really good. They have a coffee bar and some tables. If I wasn't on my way somewhere I would have enjoyed hanging out here for a bit.

44.description: Best coffee....and coffee shop...in Chicago.  Tim Coonan and his team serve up great Joe and make you feel most welcome.

24.description: Again, just a food truck review, so I can't say much about the physical location on the west side.What can I say about my coffee? I like my coffee like I like my Death Stars. Big, dark, and strong enough to destroy a planet. And while this may be me on the cusp of coffee snobbery, I think weak coffee is the equivalent of pissing into a Keurig.I was dragging myself across Wacker on my way to the office. I hadn't had my morning cup yet, so homicidal thoughts were running pretty high. Just when I thought 20 years in Cook County correctional didn't seem so bad, bam their coffee truck was right there. Literally, I wasn't paying attention to where is was walking and I actually bumped into their coffee truck.Some lady was in front of me taking her sweet ass time completely unaware that she was standing at scene of the July 17th Chicago coffee massacre. (The date this review was written) And just when I had all I could stands and I can't stands no more... she left, a nice young man within the truck provided coffee for $2 (not a bad price) and a disaster was averted.  Seriously, I wash with powdered soap, I totally can't go to prison!  Thank you Big Shoulders Coffee! Oh yeah, the actual coffee... Duh. It wasn't the strongest cup of joe I've ever had, meaning I didn't have to chew it. But it was a nice blend of fragrance and acidity. Overall a good choice. They also have some dessert items on their menu. I can never know if Jenny Craig is reading my reviews, so just to be safe I didn't partake, but you should probably try them. When was the last time you and a brownie didn't get along?

7.description: Big Shoulders is another pit stop on my Indie Coffee Passport. If I lived along the blue line, I would make this place my go-to for a cup of coffee.BSC roasts the coffee beans in-house, in-your-face. The roasting machine is located near the entrance, and it's like heaven when you're sitting at the cafe and the smell of freshly roasted beans are wafting to your corner of the cafe. Just like BK, BS will brew your coffee "your way": chemex, pour-over, catila. They have specialty lattes and will allow you to smell the syrup if you're hesitant. Had to choose between cardamom spice and toasted marshmallow today, and as big of a chai tea snob as I am, I went with toasted marshmallow. In-house lattes come in glass cups like chai tea does in India. Thick foam that makes you think you're sipping a melted marshmallow. Unimaginable and incomparable sensation unless you try it for yourself. Service was par-excellence. In-house lattes are brought to you at your table. On Twitter? Tweet about your experience and get any drink for $1. No need to hit up BK for "your way" on the dollar menu. Only thing a-miss? Didn't get a toasted marshmallow on my latte. Kinda sorta came here just for that.

49.description: Finally a cup of coffee in the Windy City that was yummy ! I had the marshmallow latte and it was great. My husband had the Horchata and he enjoyed it too. The staff was super friendly. Great place to warm up especially during a blizzard!

40.description: Great place to get a solid coffee without the pretentiousness in the city.  You can get a regular cup of coffee sure.  Or you can get something with a little extra like the horchata latte.  Drinks are made quick and you can even see them roasting their own beans.  At least I'm pretty sure that's what's going on. Wouldn't hesitate to come here again.  Also it's literally steps from the Chicago blue line stop.  What else could you want?

53.description: I love Big Shoulders coffee and have been frequenting for months now. I can't stay away from the cool crafty drinks and fun environment! The staff is amazing and the quality of the drinks are always consistent, and always on point. You can tell they care about coffee and yeah, I'll still cross the street for donuts some time, but I always get my coffee at Big Shoulders first. Try the almond latte...it's pretty amazing.

30.description: Big Shoulders Coffee is one of my go to spots for coffee! The space is bright even on the gloomiest days with their floor to ceiling windows. There is space to work at the coffee bar, community table, or right by the windows. Summer drinks are here and I'm loving both the Painted Lady and Cafe Bombon.

46.description: Being the coffee snob that I am, this place is worth being a constant stop for coffee fans! My wife was able to get an almond milk latte. Offering a healthier alternative to milk or soy, she was ecstatic. I chose one of their dark roasts served to me in a french press. What could be better than that? Love this place! Great atmosphere and knowledgeable/friendly staff. We will be going back over and over.

1.description: I just popped in here for a quick cup of coffee since I work in the area. Inside, it's a nice little cafe. It has a very soothing atmosphere, it would be an ideal place to come get some work done during a less busy time (mid to late afternoon, for example).The menu is small, which is nice for making a quick choice. I opted for a hot marshmallow latte with skim milk.For $3.90, I got a small latte. Emphasis on the SMALL. This latte was about the size of a double shot of expresso at Starbucks. It was, maybe, five or six sips of coffee, which is kind of a joke for $3.90.That being said, the coffee itself was ok. Not sure what all the hype is about. I found the flavor to be average. Not too sweet, which was nice (I hate overly sweet lattes).The best part is that the latte came with a toasted marshmallow on top! This was a nice touch and tasted great.Also, the barista was really nice and service was fast.Overall, nothing to write home about. I'll probably be back to try the horchata latte.

55.description: As you can tell from the reviews, this place is pretty great. Excellent coffee, excellent space to drink it in, helpful and friendly staff. The food quality/selection is a little lacking, but this is a coffee shop not a breakfast spot. Just keep that in mind if you want more than just coffee. Otherwise, stop in and get great beverages then buy some fresh roasted coffee to make at home.

9.description: So I went to sleep at midnight and got up at 4:30 to join a friend for a bicycle ride to Chicago's new "606" 2.7 mile jogging and bike path. I know...what was I thinking?!? This actually very enjoyable trip culminated in heading back to our respective homes, hers in River West and mine in Streeterville, but not before a stop at Big Shoulders Coffee so I'd have an extra hard time getting that second half of a proper 8 hour sleep.While I like lattes, macchiatos, cappuccinos, and other Italian named coffee fare that I don't necessarily understand, I'm kind of a purist who just likes ol' drip coffee. Big Shoulders' "fast drip" was mighty nice. It really puts the V in smooth. No burnt taste here, just rich coffee flavor with no bitterness with a smooth taste that makes me wonder why Starbucks is so damn popular. Oh yeah, well McDonalds and Miller Lite are too.They have a good selection of teas and coffee beans and a few pastries too. Apparently no hot breakfast-y type food to the lament of another reviewer. My pal says their marshmallow latte is excellent while perhaps not appreciating the irony of drinking her coffee black to save calories for "something else."Friendly service and a funkdafied atmosphere. Oh, and free wifi!

26.description: So I visited Big Shoulders, and before I placed an order, I asked the barista if I could get the key to the restroom so that I could wash my hands. She told me one customer just left the shop and took the key with him, so they were locked out and had no restroom available.No big deal. I just order a drink and forgo washing my hands (by the way, the painted lady sounds a little odd with lemonade and mint and coffee, but it's very tasty). I sat down and worked on my laptop, and throughout my stay, I noticed the other customers were freely using the restroom.Before I left, I asked the barista if the restroom was now available. She then tells me it's just past the side door, no mention of requiring a key.
